summary: Bruce Lee plays a martial-arts expert determined to help capture the narcotics dealer whose gang was responsible for the death of his sister. Lee enters a kung fu competition in an attempt to fight his way to the dealer's headquarters with the help of some friends.

reviews.content: An All Time Classic. The music is phenomenal and gives this such a unique funk/chinese identity that's really catchy. The sets are lavish and creative along with a great cast. The part that sends this over the top is easily Bruce Lee. His presence, intimidation, speed, and fighting is incredible to watch. The ending is super creative as well and a great lesson about fighting. The only knock is the audio ADR is REALLY BAD in the beginning with the master talking to Lee, but after that it gets much better. You don't need to even like martial arts movies to like this one, it's that good. Everyone should give this a try once.
It's a great movie, unlike what came out after he died.
Fun, enjoyable, and awesome. The lack of story actually helps this movie get to the awesome martial arts.

You can't get any better than this movie when it comes to martial arts movies. Many consider this one of the best or the best martial arts movies of all time. Many have copied the formula of this movie since its release. A must watch!

To start my review, I should point out I'm not too familiar with Bruce Lee's filmography. Though a long-term fan, I've only seen Big Boss and haven't known much about what his movies have to offer. That being said, this was one of my favorite action films I've seen in a long while and for reasons I was surprised to enjoy as well.
     First off, the film had costume design and film settings to create an excellent visual standard. I found myself laughing over and over again at different exploits of the comedic aspects of the visuals, like the scene where the afro-ninja calls the Chinese boss a scene out of a comic book before poising for combat, an insane pleasantry I did not expect from a 70's action film. Furthermore, the themes of supporting people of color, character-role equality, martial arts in American films, and different females, emulating a sort of gender equality was shockingly progressive for a film that came out in 1973. The amount of scenes I laughed at was the most surprising part of this film based on what I was used to in the movie 'Big Boss.'
      To move on to the demonstrations of martial arts and acting, I thought it had a range of showing off different skills and acting abilities to further keep the progressive feel to it. It show-cased a lot of Bruce Lee's ability as a fighter and acting prowess (especially in the iconic scene where he fights the man with the scar) but my one problem was that it highlighted martial arts as a comedic effect rather than trying to keep it entirely realistic. The amount of sneaking scenes, the scene where the women on heroin could flip a full grown man with one arm, and some of the character writing were slightly comical and exaggerated rather than a realistic overview. On the other hand, seeing an overview of Bruce Lee's transition from a Chinese martial arts upbringing to a more hands on solution was amazing to watch as a tribute to the way he grew up and became a renowned actor as well. Scenes with the escorts, the female escort that helped him, and the transitioning through Wing-Chun weapons; in the scene he went from staff to dual-batons to Nunchakus was awesome to see portrayed on a big-screen setting. 
   Overall, this will always be a cult classic and an all-time favorite, but the one thing that keeps me from giving it a 5-star rating is the indulgence on American culture being supreme over the martial arts. Even the scene at the end where the helicopters come over the horizon felt indulgent for a conflict that wasn't really being understood. Even though I'll always have a fondness for this classic movie, I can't forget that the real nature of Bruce Lee's fighting and acting was slightly buried under America's capitalist intentions.
Best of Movies/TV Series Collection

The movie that made Bruce Lee a star.  I was working at Grauman's Chinese theater and we showed the movie.  As an usher, I saw the movie a zillion times.  As a movie, plot and dialog, good but not great.

This movie must have been remarkable upon its release and has unfortunately aged poorly as filmmaking advanced. Enter the Dragon is not what I expected from the reviews and the legacy it holds as Bruce Lee's final film.
Decent watch for Bruce Lee fans.
The cornerstone of any martial arts movie collection.
A perfect film. What could have been of his US career had it not been cut short tragically. RIP to a legend, this is just as enjoyable in 2022.

I'm not certain if this was the first "secret invite-only martial arts tournament movie," but it's certainly the most iconic. Enter the Dragon is filled with many beautiful scenes of Hong Kong (it was filmed on-site) — especially overhead shots and shots out on the water — but that's not what you came for, is it? If you put on Enter the Dragon to watch Bruce Lee devastate countless, nameless henchmen, then you've chosen wisely. Like Bloodsport, the actual martial arts scenes are incredible. Unlike Bloodsport, the non-martial arts scenes aren't nearly as corny and the overall plot is better, if not a little campy at times. Cinephiles loves tropes (and also hate them) and sometimes it's fun to see where they come from. Again, not positive if this film was the first "evil, reclusive, ultra-rich villain who pets a white cat and is surrounded by hot babes on a secluded island with lots of artifacts and booby traps and nameless henchmen" movie, but it's the earliest one I can think of at the moment. Unfortunately, the biggest letdown of the film is that there really isn't much of a tournament at all. We're introduced to some cool fighters — Roper (John Saxon), Williams (Jim Kelly), Bolo (Bolo Yeung) — who do engage in one v. one melees, but lacked the panache of Bloodsport and Mortal Kombat when it came to the actual tournament. *Side Note* I love Bolo Yeung; complete badass and all-time fight-face guy. Because of this, we don't get the classic montage of our fighters rolling through the tournament, one ass-kicking at a time. We even had a 70s-forward score that would've paired nicely with Lee round-housing opponents in the face… oh well. I think everything there is to say about Bruce Lee has been said, so I'll just add this, "Be water, my friend." And he was. The greatest of all time. *(100/100 for the Angora cat, of course.)
The martial arts definitive film is badly acted (surprise!). Bruce Lee's scenes are remarkables and do the worth watching. 5/10
Even though this is Bruce Lee's final complete movie it's still a badass mix of Martial Arts action, Spy Thriller and Blaxploitation
Even after 50 years , its still the greatest martial arts movie of all time .

Bruce Lee is absolutely electric in this, the man's on screen presence is undeniable. Personally found it a little slow to start and there were parts where I would have preferred a little more by way of action, but it was great when it really got going, particularly as the pace picks up towards the end.

ENTER THE DRAGON (1973)
Another supposed crime against cinema has been rectified, I finally sat down to watch Bruce Lee's magnum opus. And it was madness. My knowledge of the Kung-Fu genre is disgracefully small; that Enter The Dragon reminded me so much of The Man With The Golden Gun (1974) speaks volumes to that. But that's a feeling not entirely without merit; Moore's Bond vehicle was released a mere year after Enter The Dragon and is peppered with Lee influences. It's true that Enter The Dragon is no masterpiece-the first third or so is baffling in film making terms and kind of all over the place, but the rest of it is so entertaining, it more than makes up for any stumbling about in the first half hour or so. Lee is sent by British intelligence to an Island belonging to Han, a rich bastard who is involved in drug trafficking and the sex trade. He is to partake in a martial arts tournament that is held annually on the Island. I didn't have a huge amount of time to dwell on the specifics before the action attempts to wipe your memory of the setup with admittedly great success. It plays like a spy thriller, the Bond comparisons are unavoidable but certainly not unwelcome, and the epic fight at the end of the film is fantastically choreographed. It was also impossible to watch the fight between Lee and Han at the films conclusion, in a hall of mirrors, without thinking of Scaramangas' house of fun at the conclusion of The Man With The Golden Gun. But all of that works in Enter The Dragon's favour; it's a compliment that the Bond franchise followed up a year later with so many borrowed ideas, presumably to appeal to the Asian audience.

Spoilers Spoilers Spoilers: The Good: The first half, setting up the characters and the tournament angle (which the film dropped in the second half to become James Bond in China), the music, Bolo Yeung; and the final fight in the room full of mirrors; lastly no stupid romance angle which is a plus The Bad: The repetitiveness of the second half, especially the stupidity of the guards always attacking one at a time; Bolo's finality was anti-climactic; the movie just kind of ends

The is the Citizen Kane of Martial Arts movies. It's significant both culturally and for changing the Hollywood genre. It inspired a generation of kids to take up martial arts and it ensured Bruce Lee's legacy would live on in what is his best film. A very entertaining classic that still plays well almost 50 years after it was made.
Oh my I love this 48 years ago
I watched it because it was shortly leaving Netflix.  Great martial arts scenes in a pedestrian plot.
Bruce lees memories of this great movie

This one gets 5 stars not, necessarily, because it is such a great film (which it is) but because it was so groundbreaking.   This is the film that made Bruce Lee a martial arts and international sensation.   Certain figures in entertainment and sport transcend a core group.  Bruce Lee was such an individual.   An entire generation of western born men and women can trace their interest in the martial arts to this one film.   Lee's screen presence in this one matches all the great screen idols, from Marlon Brando to James Dean.   He is mesmerizing in the lead role.   The film is supported by a great supporting cast, including John Saxon, Jim Kelly, Robert Wall, and Bolo Yeung.  This is one of those films that his been often imitated but never matched.  Great script.  Great cinematography.    Great action.   Great Loss to the film and martial arts world.

This was my entry into Bruce Lee era kung fu movies, and the fight scenes matched my high expectations. There is plenty of martial arts, in fact even more than I had expected, and the plot is a transparent way to pass the time between action scenes. From a cinematography standpoint, the camera angles of the fight scenes looked very good, and I wouldn't be surprised to find out they were cutting edge at the time. For negatives, I'm not going to get cute or overthink this one and dock the movie for having too much kung fu. However, the acting by the non-Bruce Lee characters was comical at times and distracted from the otherwise epic nature of the movie. Overall, I felt like I watched a landmark piece of cinematic history and can appreciate the legend of Bruce Lee, although the movie does age itself in the non-fighting scenes.

With little doubt I can say this is the best Bruce Lee movie, a better pacing  and more action keeps you interested all the way. Things to notice are the big difference in the amount of screen time Bruce Lee has, the movie spends many time with other characters, also has a lot of spy/James Bond elements.


Funny how Warner Bros tried to replicate the "Chinese Movie" feeling.
With pretty girls and awesome kung fu, Bruce lee frees up his posthumous film with martial stride and stoic pride.
Bruce Lee (the legend) is in it, enough said to be praiseworthy for me.

I can see why they kind of poked fun at Bruce Lee in Tarantino's last movie. He was kind of full of himself and kind of cocky. I can't help but feel that this is a Hollywood glamorization of martial arts and all the philosophy that comes with it that should be acknowledged and not glanced over. Interesting seeing how people live on their boats in the Hong Kong bay area, like a sort of ghetto. I really like all the fight sequences throughout the movie. Bro, the afro brother took out the two cops and then straight up jacked the cop car lmao! I can admire and respect the camera work. All the zoom outs and zoom ins he does and the way the camera moves to convey a certain feeling about the scene. There's actually some pretty funny moments throughout. Lee's little screeches are hilarious. It's part spy movie as well. The last couple of fight sequences were nice in the mirror room and the big fight in the courtyard. Great stylish martial arts movie with a good sense of humor that is also social commentary on the drug cartel business.

Enter the Dragon was one of Bruce Lee's last movies released after his death. It's a great film that along with Lee elevated the martial arts genre of movies into pop culture consciousness. Lee is not a great actor but is a powerful performer showing his incredible moves and fighting techniques that are now iconic. The film features a fun action packed story with the classical tropes of martial arts movies, insane fighting scenes, action, and organized crime. Jim Kelly and John Saxon play two charismatic characters that add to Bruce Lee's performance. Its an insane and bombastic action film that still works today.

Even in its mirrored etiquette of labyrinths, burrows and sentimental typhoons, it doesn't shy away from the star discipline of the martial-arts, what the master, Bruce Lee, fought for through ruptured bones, blistering daylights and grandiose dragons.

It is not fighting just for the sake of fighting, it has a purpose behind it and the fight scenes although consuming hefty screen-time never overshadow its purpose and that is where the beauty of this film lies.

I don't why, but I simply didn't expect this to be so silly. It's basically Mortal Kombat without the magic…and with, ya know, a plot. Not that that's a bad thing…I like Mortal Kombat, so a better version of that is a win. The action style and cinematography has been parodied so much it's hard not to laugh at times (fight grunts, quick zooms), but Lee is impossible to deny. He wasn't just great in the combat; the dude was just a straight-up movie star.

Surprisingly terrible horrible boring movie starring Bruce lee. This movie was all over the place and I didn't care one bit about this movie. Maybe it's because it's old but who knows. Very forgettable movie.

Lee (Bruce Lee), a highly proficient Shaolin martial artist and instructor from Hong Kong, is approached by Braithwaite, a British intelligence agent investigating the suspected crime lord Han. Lee is persuaded to attend a high-profile martial arts competition on Han's private island to gather evidence that will prove Han's involvement in drug trafficking and prostitution. Shortly before his departure, Lee also learns that the man responsible for his sister's death, O'Hara, is working as Han's bodyguard on the island. Also fighting in the competition are Roper (John Saxon), an indebted gambling addict, and fellow Vietnam war veteran Williams (Jim Kelly). At the end of the first day, Han gives strict orders to the competitors not to leave their rooms. Lee makes contact with undercover operative Mei Ling and sneaks into Han's compound, looking for evidence. He is discovered by several guards but manages to escape. The next morning, Han orders his giant guard Bolo to kill the guards in public for failing their duties. After the execution, Lee faces O'Hara in the competition and ends up killing him. With the day's competition over, Han confronts Williams, who had also left his room the previous night to exercise. Han believes Williams to be the intruder and beats him to death when he refuses to cooperate. Han then reveals his drug operation to Roper, hoping that he will join his organisation. He also implicitly threatens to imprison Roper, along with all the other martial artists who joined Han's tournaments in the past, if Roper refuses. Despite being initially intrigued, Roper refuses after learning of Williams's fate...

Upon release, the film initially received mixed reviews from several critics, including a favorable review from Variety magazine. The film eventually went on to be well-received by most critics, and it is widely regarded as one of the best films of 1973. Critics have referred to Enter the Dragon as "a low-rent James Bond thriller", a "remake of Dr. No" with elements of Fu Manchu. J.C. Maçek III of PopMatters wrote, "Of course the real showcase here is the obvious star here, Bruce Lee, whose performance as an actor and a fighter are the most enhanced by the perfect sound and video transfer. While Kelly was a famous martial artist and a surprisingly good actor and Saxon was a famous actor and a surprisingly good martial artist, Lee proves to be a master of both fields." Many acclaimed newspapers and magazines reviewed the film. Variety described it as "rich in the atmosphere", the music score as "a strong asset" and the photography as "interesting". Additionally, The New York Times gave the film a rave review. The review stated "The picture is expertly made and well-meshed; it moves like lightning and brims with color. It is also the most savagely murderous and numbing hand-hacker (not a gun in it) you will ever see anywhere." Rotten Tomatoes critical consensus reads, "Badass to the max, Enter the Dragon is the ultimate kung-fu movie and fitting (if untimely) Bruce Lee swan song.". In 2004, the film was deemed "culturally significant" by the Library of Congress and selected for preservation in the National Film Registry.

With a budget, at least in this Bruce Lee case, there´s some sort of production value. We even get a musical score by the master himself Lalo Shifrin. The Martial Arts genre is not really my genre, and "Enter The Dragon" does not change that to be honest. But, this film is much "better" than "The Big Boss" and "Game of Death" in my book. "Enter The Dragon" would be Lee's final completed film appearance before his death on 20 July 1973 at age 32. An American and Hong Kong co-production, it premiered in Los Angeles on 19 August 1973, one month after Lee's death. The film went on to gross an estimated US$350 million worldwide (equivalent to more than $1 billion adjusted for inflation), against a budget of $850,000. Having earned over 400 times its budget, it is one of the most profitable films of all time. "Enter the Dragon" is also considered one of the most influential action films of all time, with its success contributing to mainstream worldwide interest in martial arts as well as inspiring numerous fictional works including action films, television shows, fighting games, comic books, manga and anime.

Classic martial arts movie that remains the standard for the genre today, along with cementing Bruce Lee as a superstar.  The cast is excellent across the board, with Jim Kelly making a nice debut as Williams while the John Saxon brings gravitas as the conman, Roper (along with some nice moves, as he was actually a black belt himself).  Of course, it is Bruce Lee who dominates every moment he is on screen, oozing the power and charisma that creates a superstar.  The speed and power in delivers in the fight scenes is undeniable (his nunchuck routine remains iconic), while he also shows range as a man on a mission while also seeking revenge.  Behind the camera, director Robert Clouse crafts what is essentially a James Bond movie, but an effective one, with a nice mix of characters and a charming villain (a superb Kien Shih), along with some brilliant action set pieces (the final fight in the mirror room remains standout).  All in all, one of the best of films by both Bruce Lee and the martial arts genre.
Greatest martial arts movie of all time.

A riveting Hollywood Bruce Lee movie!

Robert Clouse's martial arts action picture Enter the Dragon (1973) is a bittersweet swan song for Bruce Lee to make as his final completed film before his tragic death. Enter the Dragon is entertaining demonstrating Bruce Lee's acting chops and kung fu kicks and punches with deadly speed. Lee makes fighting look effortless here. He was clearly in peak physical condition, strong and fast as he ever was, so it's especially sad that he died so young. 

Bruce Lee is still a legendary actor, martial artist, philosopher, and pop culture icon, rightfully so. He was charming, charismatic, funny, skilled, smart, and elegant in his graceful approach to life and combat. He wanted to spread Chinese kung fu's prowess to the world. At least he got to do that with classics of cinema like Enter the Dragon. Bruce Lee's character Lee from Enter the Dragon will live on forever as a master of discipline, thinker of martial arts philosophies, and fearsome fast fighter like no other. Rest in paradise, Bruce Lee.

Angela Mao is killer as Bruce Lee's martial arts adept sister Su Lin in Enter the Dragon. Her spinning kicks look flawless and fast in the captivating chase sequence towards the beginning of Enter the Dragon. Mao is both lovely and cool as the powerful martial artist Su Lin. 

John Saxon is hilarious and suave as the charming debonair Roper. His fight scenes are the next best thing after Bruce Lee's, honestly. Sek Kin is cool, cruel, and memorable as Enter the Dragon's ruthless villain Han. His metallic hand and knife hand are excellent violence gimmicks to keep Bruce Lee on his toes. Ahna Capri is gorgeous as the voluptuous Tania on Han's island. Her natural chemistry with Saxon is nice to see too. Jim Kelly is cool as the blacksploitation type character Williams. His combat sequences are neat and his dialogue is so silly that you cannot help but laugh along with him. 

Robert Wall is despicable as Oharra in another great performance from him in a Bruce Lee film. Betty Chung is so beautiful and intriguing as Mei Ling the undercover spy in Enter the Dragon. I wish she was in the film even more. Bolo Yeung is terrifying as Han's vicious henchman Bolo.

Robert Clouse's direction is less artful than Lo Wei or Bruce Lee's direction for Lee's previous kung fu classics, but Clouse finds his stride with massive Hollywood production elements and fun scenes. He takes you from Hong Kong to a remote island with all the lively entertainment you could want in a movie. His mirror sequence is brilliant like Han's first fight in his lair. There's a lot of creativity and parody of James Bond elements too that are fun.

Michael Allin's script is a fun mixture of martial arts, crime drama, and espionage thriller with twists all around and a seedy tone. Yao Chung Chang's editing is stellar with Enter the Dragon's run-time remaining a brisk 102 minutes long.

Gil Hubbs' cinematography shoots the fights with a stylish flair that is very 1970's exaggerated for fun. His wide shots of Hong Kong and the island are gorgeous and a neat timepiece for the era. All the shots for Han's fights are psychedelic and trippy with a ton of filmmaking tricks that are daring for a Hollywood movie. Shen Chien's art direction is pretty with a classic Chinese aesthetic for everything alongside Chu Sheng-Hsi's lavish groovy costumes. Lalo Schifrin's score is exciting with a suspense to it that helps give Enter the Dragon some dramatic weight.

I should mention there's a funny cameo from a young Jackie Chan as a stunt man that Bruce Lee kills in Han's base of operations in the middle of the movie. I believe that Bruce Lee also got his legendary mentor Ip Man himself to cameo as the elderly man rowing Bruce Lee's boat to Han's ship in the start of Enter the Dragon.

In the end, Enter the Dragon is a legendary film for being Bruce Lee's final finished project and a completing delightful experience to watch countless times over. Thank you for the movies, Bruce.

"Your battle with the guards was magnificent, your skills are extraordinary & I was going to ask you to join us"  Just sit back & be in awe as the 
master that was Bruce Lee, shows his supreme  & never betterd skills as he agrees to be a spy & bring down a reclusive crime lord, using an invitation to a martial arts tournament as cover.

If you haven't seen this movie yet, check it out sometime. You'll enjoy it.
One of the greatest Kung Fu films of all time

A magical performance from Bruce Lee that draws you in closer than those crash-zooms, an iconic lush score that is East-meets-West funk, a James Bond by another name, part spy, part martial arts film; Enter The Dragon is a hilarious, meditative, spirited, creative and powerful period film. The first half is a solid, ensemble detective/spy film, with well-drawn characters, the second half is a rip-roaring martial arts extravaganza; the fight scenes under ground using the sticks and the nunchucks and around the elevator before he's captured is electric even today, very modern and influential, and the end fights with the huge cast of extras is a really exciting third act, especially in today's age of CGI.
It's serious and silly, it's dated and timeless, it's a hell of a lot of fun and it's got a little bit of heart and a little bit of spirituality.
Unless you grew up with martial arts films this doesn't hold up today.
Well-paced but dated.

What a movie! I can't believe it took me this long to watch it and I'm glad I did. Great movie. Bruce Lee's charisma is undeniable. Awesome fight scenes. Excellent locations and production design. Really dug this. Solid concept, great execution.

However, the cast was definitely awesome, all fight sequences were passable, the performances were great, and it gave much to the martial arts film in general. Bruce Lee had toothpick legs. No wonder he wore baggy pants all the time.But that's beside the point. The first 30-45 minutes is such slow buildup. You could fast forward through a big chunk of this and not miss anything important. Do NOT, though, miss the final fight in front of the mirrors.
The greatest martial arts movie I have ever seen.  Bruce Lee is amazing and I have yet to see anything that comes close to this classic.

Enter the Dragon is a structural mess of story. It starts out alright because it takes a few minutes to establish all our main protagonists so we can see why they are participating in the tournament. But once the characters start heading to the tournament and all throughout the tournament proceedings it is a jumbled mess of nonsense. It was so hard to track what anyone was doing or hoping to attain at any given moment. The tournament itself lacked any logical structure. In fact for a good portion of the movie I had a hard time figuring out which person was supposed to be the primary villain of the story. Also there were a few actors in the film that never convinced me that they had much martial arts talent, particularly John Saxon, which is a big problem in this type of movie. I’m not saying he is completely worthless in the fight scenes, but it was hard to buy him defeating some of the more skilled stuntmen. The reason I talk about all that frustration I experienced with the plot of the film and some of the actors, is because I’m trying to mentally reconcile the fact that the movie was full of flaws and yet I had a blast watching it. It’s so odd to have your brain saying something is not good, but at the same time in the back of your head a voice keeps telling you “This is awesome!” It touched on some deeper more visceral part of my mind that reacts on instinct instead of logic The fight choreography is remarkable, and loaded with exaggerated sound effects that make it feel more intense. Robert Clouse knows how to shoot the fights to keep them exciting, and also knows the perfect moment to utilize slow motion to increase the impact of any given kick or punch. Even when I didn’t fully understand the motivations of the two characters in a fight it didn’t matter to me because I was excited about the skill involved and how it would end. Part of the reason I found Enter the Dragon so engaging is the remarkable talent of Bruce Lee. I knew he was amazing at martial arts, and the fights that he staged in this film prove his skill. What I didn’t know before watching this movie is how charming he was as an actor. He has a suave style that makes you instantly like him the moment he walks on screen. He has a magnetic personality, and he also can portray sorrow and other complex emotions. It increased my emotional investment in the film simply because I felt he was impacted by all that happened to his character. And since he was the one in peril in the climax, I was more worried than I might have been in any other nonsensical movie like this one. Needless to say, I struggled with some important aspects of Enter the Dragon, and under any other circumstances I could see myself saying it was terrible and that I hate it. However, I had a ton of fun watching the movie, and I’d love to see more from Bruce Lee.
Not as memorable as I thought it would be. I really loved the goofy characters and the mirror scene though.

A Truly Classic Action Movie

A pop culture gem of a film, watching "Enter the Dragon" is like watching a comic book come to life but without any of the superpowers. Lee's choreography and super hard work/passion shines especially when placed in well-shot locations that take advantage of different fighting scenarios.
The entire film crew deliver a piece of work that is rich with culture, colours, music, period pieces from the 70s, and of course, action where the post production sound effects make you feel every bone crushing hit the actors deliver to each other.
The film is light on plot, but honestly, the plot is not the focus, but rather, an excusable vehicle to showcase Lee's unprecedented work where the villains get what they deserve and the heroes do their best to reach their dreams. 
The amount of passion put into the film just leaps off the screen and everybody involved deserves an applause. There is a reason why it sparked the popularity of Martial Arts and helped inspire many others from filmmakers to bodybuilders. I bow my head down to the late great master...but I'll make sure to keep my eyes on the prize!
Stylish, impressive and tremendous influence for generations of fighters.
one of the best Bruce Lee movies

I don't see what the fuss is about. It was pretty good, though cheezy and campy, kung fu movie full of action and Bruce Lee being a silly badass. The story was ok, the plot of contrived, but it was entertaining nonetheless. Couple comedic moments, couple brutal moments, nothing surprising or unexpected. The effects were cheap, the sound was bad, the acting was embarrassing.
Superb martial arts action, with great supporting players, definitely Bruce Lee at his finest!
just the mirrored-room fight scene alone makes this worth a viewing

When it comes to martial arts no one has achieved as much popularity as pop culture legend Bruce Lee, even if only appeared in five feature films with only one being an American production: The influential "Enter the Dragon". Considering its impact in pop culture, is this the classic many people claim it is? 

Lee is a highly skilled martial artist that is tasked by the British intelligence to investigate a crime lord called Han, by attending martial arts tournament. 

When you watch any genre movie you have different expectations: With horror we expect good scares, comedy with good jokes, spy movies with cool/memorable gadgets and tremendous action sequences, etc. So when it comes to martial arts movies we expect some well-choreographed action sequences and to be highly entertaining and "Enter the Dragon" succeeds at this. Being a B movie, this Bruce Lee film has a cheesy plot, wooden acting, hilariously dated special effects, forgettable characters and eye roll inducing dialog. However despite its numerous flaws this film stands out and deserves its reputation. "Enter the Dragon" has outstanding fighting scenes (which is not surprising considering that most people in here are martial artists but still, the results are tremendous), spectacular stunts, the score is fantastic, the pacing is spot on, and overall it is quite entertaining. However the greatest thing about this film isn't the martial arts themselves but the incredible production design as it is quite simple but surprisingly effective and unforgettable. From the simple tournament setting to the villain´s iconic lair, this production design has been imitated to death ("Man with the Golden Gun" and "Mortal Kombat" being the first ones that come to mind) but never duplicated. 

"Enter the Dragon" is a well-made film that not only fulfills its duty of giving the audience fantastic action sequences but it also shines due to its production design. A highly entertaining film worth seeing.

3/5 stars

Pretty cheesy.  At times it came across more like an Austin powers movie than a serious movie.  

There were a few stunningly good fight scenes with lots of cheesy scenes.

I probably should give this a 2.5 but given that it was the first Bruce Lee movie I've seen and this is supposedly one of his best I'm giving a slight sympathy boost.

The movie title was mysteriously dramatic and Chinese martial arts was an unknown deadly art of self-defence besides boxing-style fist punching and football-like kicking. The European name 'Bruce' together with the Chinese simple-spelt 'Lee' was an unforgettable name for the most famous kung fu fighter to start the kung fu movie era. The villain was a classic James Bond gangster-style/ radio commentary-style dialogue as every word can be heard clearly, as if the voice is heard inside a noise-proof studio room ;;

The quintessential Kung-Fu action flick that made Bruce Lee an international star.

Despite being a tad dated, this is still a fantastic action movie through and through. 

It's well-directed, the music by Lalo Schifrin is great, and the action is fast and well-choreographed.

All three of the main leads are also great (Bruce Lee, John Saxon, Jim Kelly).
If it wouldnt be for Bruce Lees quicker than quick moves, this movie would just be a James Bond look-a-like. Sadly the story is totally week, though some of the action pays the bill.

Danny Peary's book Cult Movies makes these points:
-kung fu pics took a position in reaction to Communist Chinese film narratives: "Chinese of same social standing - but of different martial arts schools - fighting one another; with heroes working individually to defeat a villain who does not represent an oppressive government... but is a a gangster, racketeer, and a murderer, whom the government has no love for either."
-the flaws in the film:  Lee unhappily departed from his trademark (i.e.taking the side of the little guy) to be a James Bond figure; inconsistencies in the story; no time element.
-what sets Lee apart from other 'chop socky' stars: no root philosophical base, own stunts.  And oh yeah, Lee is "the most charismatic sexual film personality of the period".  The film objectifies his body and makes sexual metaphors about him.
The best action movie that one can watch with 0-end full thrill.

Enter the Dragon has good action sequences with the last fight being excellent, that entire ending sequence is superb, the plot is solid and the film is very well made and quite entertaining, but it is still a bit overrated as the characters are rather forgettable, the film is too simplistic and some of its parts are very problematic. It's a good film, but far from a great one.

Bruce Lee's final film and one of his finest. Enter the Dragon has brilliant fighting sequences and beautiful Asian set design, but the addition of blaxploitation was not the wisest idea, which ruined the mood.

Enter the Dragon (1973) ????
Classic action film details Lee who investigates strange island fortress headed by dangerous crime lord hosting "epic" martial arts tournament. Vivid, dizzying, dazzling; a masterpiece of action (many scenes and images have become iconic). Final sequence in mirror room will drive you right up the wall. High-powered excitement all the way.

Lee: "You have offended my family. And you have offended the Shaolin temple."

Enter the Dragon isn't what I call a masterpiece of film making or anything near outstanding when it comes to it's characters, acting or story line, but honestly, who comes to see a Bruce Lee movie expecting that? I sure didn't. Just pointing out the obvious things that anyone would find if those chose to watch this with a critical thinking mind, which you would easily spot the problems straight away. But the movie dose deliver on one thing and that's the punch, with it's flawless Martial art fight scenes. This is a very enjoyable movie with Bruce Lee showing off his awesomeness in his last ever film.

Without a doubt, the best part of this movie is the fight scenes and I know it's quite obvious to say that, but the fights are the highlight of the film. I felt every hit, punch, kick and smack in all the fight scenes and it's all by the power of Bruce Lee himself. It's glorious to watch and it's by far the best on screen fight scene from any movie I've seen, I mean the amount of detail that Lee puts in his fights are just extraordinary. There's no quick cuts or shaky cam used in those scenes, as it was all naturally filmed. I would go that far and say it's true art *like the title* "Martial arts."

This movie doesn't have the most intriguing story, as it's more of a prop itself to hang up in the background so we can get to the real juice stuff. So people can't say it doesn't have a story because it dose, but it's too silly and hasn't got anything remotely interesting that can grab my interest on what's going on. It's also a slow burn at the start, as it takes awhile to get where it needs to go, but it's worth the wait.

The acting was pretty bad, as I notice countless times that some of the actors have no emotional on their face when there's scenes that's suppose to be intense or somewhat funny. The editing is really off as well and it's mostly to do with it's weird cuts that comes out of nowhere that feels out of place.

Overall Enter the Dragon is a very enjoyable movie with plenty of fun to be have. But what really sucks is that this is the final film we will ever see of the unique, extreme, but talented, Bruce Lee. The legacy will live on.

Bonus fact: Jackie Chan makes a small cameo in the movie. The title of the video is wrong, but hey. www.youtube.com/watch?v=U8CtOqJy6xM

Martial arts film from 1973 that has gained notoriety as being the last film made by its main star Bruce Lee. Lee died just prior to its premiere.
I admit to having little exposure to the genre. My 'kung-fu' movie education has perhaps only included the Karate Kid films!
However this is a classic and worthy of everybody watching before they die.
The fight choreography by Lee is a joy. Despite some dodgy dubbing and sound effects added post - production.
I am going to have to watch other films in the genre.
The plot involves a kung-fu tournament being held on an island near the then UK controlled Hong Kong.
The owner of the island and organiser of the tournament Han is being monitored by the British for dodgy opium linked criminal activities.
Lee is invited to the tournament as a contestant and asked by the British to help capture Han with evidence to bring down his empire.
However Lee has other reasons to go for Han. Including the death of his sister and the dishonour brought to his shaolin temple by Han.
I couldn't help but spot a few similarities to the Bond franchise! 
Han has a metal hand (Dr. No).
He strokes a white cat (Blofeld).
The Bond films follow this film a year later in 1974 with The Man With The Golden Gun set in Macau and Hong Kong and featuring a hall of mirrors scene that mirrors a scene towards the end of this.
A musical score is provided by Mission:Impossible composer Lalo Schifrin.
Excellent film.
Bruce Lee's last work provides one of the best martial arts films in film history with a good story and fantastic performance by Lee.

If ENTER THE DRAGON has a failing, itâ??s that too much time is spent on John Saxonâ??s Roper, rather than Lee or even the late Jim Kelly, as Saxon- while fine- wasnâ??t anywhere near their league as a martial artist. Thankfully, Lee never really takesÂ tooÂ much of a backseat to Saxon (who mainly exists to romance Hanâ??s island madam- Ahna Capri), and all of the memorable action sequences are Leeâ??s. Highlights include his nunchaku battle with Hanâ??s guards (look quickly for Jackie Chan as the guard who gets his neck snapped), and the final, brutal battle with the claw-handed Hand in a maze of mirrors (my choice for one of the most memorable action sequences of all time).

Not the best martial arts film ever made.  I'm not even sure it's Lee's best film.  It's his most professional, well-made film, but he's used better in other films.  This is really the primal martial arts film for western audiences, and probably the best film to introduce people to the genre.  The blend of a kind of standard martial arts tournament plot with a James Bond-type premise, and John Saxon and Jim Kelly almost sharing the lead provide an easy in for the uninitiated.
Legendary action icon Bruce Lee kicks all sorts of ass in "Enter The Dragon," a superior kung fu flick with amazing fight choreography and an electric atmosphere.
Very Good Movie I Love Bruce Lee RIP Bruce Lee

Bruce Lee is the man, but I do have to say that the Zucker/Abrahams/Zucker "A Fistful of Yen" segment in "The Kentucky Fried Movie" has completely ruined me from being able to take this film seriously ("What was that? This is not a chawade. We need total concentwation." or "These are lost drunken men who don't know where they are, but do care! And these are men who know where they are and care, but don't drink."). That aside and some goofy mugging by Bruce Lee, this film is an absolute martial arts classic. The story is super basic (the evil Han is hosting a martial arts tournament and Bruce is sent in by a spy agency to stop Han's evil doings) but the story perfectly facilitates lots of kung-fu action. An honest assessment of this film is that it's pretty dated and actually pretty corny when viewed through modern sensibilities, but despite that, Bruce Lee is amazing! Bruce with the nunchuks. Bruce taking out a tunnel full of henchmen. And Bruce striding through the crowd to get to Han at the end. Bruce is just awesome and that's what carries the film. John Saxon always seemed like odd casting as one of the three main leads and is passable, even if his martial arts was not. Jim Kelly however is quite good in role, which led to his underrated film "Black Belt Jones." Look for a young Sammo Hung as the Shaolin fighter Bruce has a demonstration match with in the opening. Jackie Chan is apparently one of the prison thugs who fights Bruce, although I couldn't spot him. Also, Keye Luke did uncredited dubbing for Dr. Han. The film also earns at least 1/2 a star for the terrific and iconic Lalo Schifrin music. Bruce's previous Hong Kong films are better demonstrations of his martial arts skills, but this film features an overall better production value and slickness his previous films lacked.

I remember as a kid when my father used me to buy a Betamax tape on this one. And that funky Enter the Dragon intro tune is just hardcore! Enter the Dragon made me became not just a Bruce Lee fan. But a martial arts fan in general. I can't imagine any other actor that can do Bruce Lee's charisma. I mean wow, just simply look at him. His incredible physique and talent as a leading actor. I would say, this film is so funky, with that 70's music style and that mixed up very well with the martial arts theme and the characterization. You can see in each other's martial arts abilities. This is 70's and some martial arts nor action fight scenes of today, are still imitating some of the well choreographed moves of Enter the Dragon. I used to love some of the characters such as Williams and that Afro guy Roper and their roles fits them so well. If you used to be a gamer and played Tekken. Now we're talking. In short, this Bruce Lee film made him not just a popular actor, but an Icon. And this film is Iconic. 5 stars all the way!
Still a classic film, dated but great popcorn fun!!!

The First Martial Arts Film Produced By An American Company, Enter The Dragon Is An Excellent Mix Of Martial Arts & A Crime/Spy Thriller. An Excellently Written Piece Of Cinema Which See's A Martial Artist Recruited By The American Government To Enter A Martial Arts Competition, In Which He Was Invited To Spy On The Competition's Host. Recruited Mainly Due To The Fact The U.S. Need Proof Of His Illegal Activity To Shut Han (The Host) Down. An Excellent Film With Some Decent Character Development Thanks To Nicely Placed & Timed Flashback Sequences. This Is A Film Where The Cast Give Great Solid Performances & Made Bruce Lee An International Star. Look Out For Fellow Martial Artists, Angela Mao, Sammo Hung & Jackie Chan In Small Roles.

All action movies have a fist and some pack a punch. Some action movies have a brain beyond the speedy delivery of cheesy one-liners. And a few action movies have a graceful soul, a wise heart and the breath of a dragon. Bruce Lee deserves the immorality this film gave him.

When a movie has black belts of one style performing white belt moves while a man makes his sloppy own style that you can tell doesn't hit anyone while filming, you know that all this movie is supposed to be is a slap in the face by a pretentious martial arts dropout who's a better actor than fighter.  All "Enter the Dragon" was supposed to be is an insult to martial arts that are not the style he invented, an insult to people like Ken Ogawa and Yip Man.  Even then, it's not a well-constructed one during the last half.  The whole film is original, lacking proper fight scenes, logic, and character development.

The absolute granddaddy of martial arts films, Enter The Dragon is the template for complete kick ass action.

It also helps to have Bruce Lee, the film's charismatic lead, in control alongside John Saxon and Jim Kelly on a mission to establish bad boy Mr Han Man's activities on his island fortress.

Suffice to say a lot of bones get broken, a lot of sneaking around goes belly up, and one man's idea of 'one' is everyone else's idea of many when picking from a line up.

This was Bruce Lee's swan song - in his last complete film - escalating the genre into a greater level of public consciousness.

This kung fu classic still works today with it's impressive fight choreography, tight direction, and memorable moments featuring the legend himself, Bruce Lee. The story is a simple revenge tale, but the island locale and diverse group of fighters in the tournament keep it fresh engaging. Bruce Lee really was the man, and his astounding speed and martial arts skills were in a league of their own, and his presence on-screen is felt. The climactic fight in the hall of mirrors is exceptional and the villain was almost James Bond-esque with a deadly, interchangeable left hand. It's a shame that this was Lee's first and final film in Hollywood before his death, but he left behind a great legacy which spawned many imitators *cough* Mortal Kombat!
One of the best martial arts movies ever!

Enjoyable, over-the-top, with laughable and serious moments, ingenious quasi-realistic choreography and real stunts, entertaining score, though a little too cliched and expository for these days, Enter The Dragon still is, Bruce Lee's masterpiece.

Hearing Bruce Lee while fighting is unintentionally hilarious, while also seeing his facial expressions doing the same thing. With that out of the way, Enter The Dragon is one huge martial arts classic that even has been regarded as one of the best films of 1973 and Culturally or Historically Significant by the National Film Registry. Being a fan of Martial Arts films, I was anxious to watch this, and the result was great. Bruce Lee is still the master even after Jackie Chan or Jet Lee, or even Tony Jaa. This film can also be a huge excuse to watch Lee doing what he does better: scream! Just kidding, kicking everyone's asses with that "I'm Invincible" face he always carries.

Bruce also proved to be a legit actor, as his performance was actually decent and his English also good. It's curious how this movie has little to none character development, and yet the characters are memorable; maybe it's because we see what they can do and they do it in a very cool way. Transformers does the same but the result isn't nearly as good. I guess they have some charm we can't help but feel, as they martial arts skills easily drags us in. Undeniably a classic.

Enter the Dragon still works today, but maybe not the same way. There's Ong Bak and many other films that had shown much more skilled or believable fight movements and martial arts, but something they will never reach, it's the charm that Bruce Lee had in every film, and this one is no exception at all. I feel like doing some punches and scream like I having my balls removed. HHHYYAAAAAAHHH!

This is the most important Martial Arts film of all time. Not the best, not even close, but still a great one and the most influential one ever made. Up to that point in the U.S., Martial Art movies were cultish at best. Yes some of the heroes like James Bond and John Shaft used a martial art move or two, but full MA motion pictures were relegated to second run theaters on a triple bill. Add American star John Saxon and introduce a new African American star in badass Jim Kelly. The fighting in this is second to none, the story is meh and the acting is great by the three leads, especially Bruce. This is the movie that made him a superstar but unfortunately he did not live to see it's success, passing away 3 months prior at the extremely young age of 32. P.S. If you look closely, you can spot Jackie Chan. In the scene where Bruce is fighting everyone off with a Bo staff, Jackie comes up behind Bruce and gets him an rear choke hold, of course Bruce turns the tables on Jackie and snaps his 17-year-old neck. 

http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/4/4c/Jackie_Chan_Fist.JPG
Watch this movie for the Kung-fu, and nothing else.

Enter the Dragon works as a great action film, a low-budget Kung fu version of Dr. No and an exploration of Chinese culture all at once, and it rides all this and more without ever becoming just another action vehicle for Bruce Lee.

Enter the Dragon isn't perfect, because it's pacing is inconsistent in places and it doesn't explore as much Chinese culture as it could have. But considering that it transfers the story aspect of Kung Fu into a sensible and original thriller plot, it functions well.
Enter the Dragon has a really original concept, taking themes of a Kung Fu tournament and moving it into a James Bond style thriller with absence of the gadgets but maintaining all the thrills and action. Except that the action is all well choreographed full-on Kung Fu fights which makes it a brutal contact experience with plenty of punches and kicks, and that's just cool. Really, the ambitious scope of the story makes it more than it needed to be and could have been, and Robert Clouse's direction ensures that it's stylishly shot and full of appealing imagery, as well as a good musical score. 
Enter the Dragon is a well written film, and although it's a bit all over the place at times, it is constantly a strong one. With a powerful lead from Bruce Lee and the presence of the first Black martial arts film star Jim Kelly, it has a diverse cast. Even John Saxon looks like Sean Connery, the best James Bond.
And the appearances of a young Bolo Yeung and Jackie Chan make it a nostalgic piece too, with Bolo Yeung's aggressive darkness making him a strong villain.
So really, Enter the Dragon is packed to the brim with nostalgia and Chinese culture, as well as strong acting, a good story and some kickass action which help Enter the Dragon to transcend it's scattered pacing. It's full of great imagery and is a memorable send off for the late Bruce Lee who died way before his time and missed the premiere of Enter the Dragon unfortunately.
Bruce at his butt-kicking best!

Probably the most famous martial arts movie of all time.Great fight sequences, but in particular I love the way they rip of Dr No (James Bond)You don't need to love Kung Fu to enjoy this movie, just a love of great 'B' movies.

A great film, the choreography is 2nd to none. My favourite scene was the fight Lee had with Oharra, especially the quote 'boards don't fight back' which was delivered perfectly. Just wished there was more depth to the plot and a bit more depth to the characters.

I saw this movie when it first came out, I was 12 years old and I've spent the last 40 years admiring the man and his teachings. This is his gift to us on film, ENJOY!

Bruce Lee was not only a real martial artist, he was a real actor, too.  His character in Enter the Dragon has the requisite unflappability of an action hero and Shaolin monk, but the persona is by no means wooden.  His eyes and face can reveal a range of emotion, and are especially animated in the slow-motion shots that help make this movie so visually appealing.  His voice, too, un-dubbed throughout for practically the only time in his career, is composed but forceful.  When he says to the bad guy, "You have offended my family, and you have offended the Shaolin temple," the line carries the clear unspoken addendum "and now you must die" not only because it's the obvious thing to say at the climax of a martial arts movie but because of the way Lee delivers it.  Not just any fighter can act, nor vice versa, but Bruce Lee did both.  His skills probably never had a better-looking showcase than Enter the Dragon, with its loving shots of junks and people in a Hong Kong bay and its creative final showdown in a hall of mirrors.  On many lists it's been coronated the "official" best martial arts movie ever, and it's easy to see why and to believe it.
If Bloodsport met a James Bond film you'd have Enter the Dragon, except with more cheesy '70s cinematography.

I am a sucker for kung fu.  If made today, it would not be regarded as the classic it is, but that is because it was not made today.  Today's movie would not allow for a combination of art and martial art.

The story is dull, as is the acting and characters. A movie like this in today's age is seen as cheesy and over acted, but that's really the whole charm of the kung fu film right? Though it is flawed, the movie is focused on showcasing Bruce Lee just flat out kicking ass. On that front, Enter the Dragon definitely delivers.
Been watching this for 40 years...still the best kung fu movie ever!

Lee's genre defying martial art epic is an utter blast to behold. It's slick, well told and the action sequences are truly stunning to see unfold. It's restricted to what it should and needs to be, never excessive or unnecessary in any scene. Lee is magnificent and really epitomises the action hero throughout with memorable quips and iconography that have stood the test of time. It's climax and finale is a thing of utter beauty.

Poor dubbing is an inelegant solution to language barrier issues. It cheapens what are already very basic performances, given by actors who are more placeholders than characters. But identities and motivations are only obligatory garnish in a genre based on physical conflicts between players, and the film is occasionally satisfying where these are concerned. Some of the fight sequences blur together with too little emotion or variety, but the film achieves moments of buoyancy when Bruce Lee lets fly.

The martial arts movie of ALL martial arts movies. Such a simple concept, thought provoking (see the first 15 minutes), and when it came to the fighting it was raw martial arts. My only regret is that this is Lee's last completed film before he passed away.

Easily the greatest martial artist in the greatest martial arts film ever.

Bruce Lee is legendary!! What can l say

Not as classic as Jackie Chan flicks but close.
Classic Bruce lee, enjoyed it more than I thought I would

This would be the first martial arts movie I've seen and I must say it is very entertaining, for the most part at least. Bruce Lee is great in all the fights he staged. However I feel the supporting cast doesn't have much of a purpose and thats a shame, because the film could have had some potential layers. Still its massive fun, and should be seen since it is Bruce Lee's last movie after his untimely death. Great fun, go ahead and watch it even if you're not a fan of "classic movies".

I would have prefered if this had of remained a tournament based kung-fu flick. That aside and ignoring the James Bond type plot line their is enough mayhem, action and quality fight scenes throughout. John Saxon as always is the balls and the legend Jim Kelly gets more pussy than John Shaft.

Can we all just be completely honest about this movie and admit that it is not the best martial arts movie of all time?  It's not made particularly well, and the plot is sort of dumb.  Bruce Lee is amazing, no doy/no duh, but the things around him are not really.  It's an enjoyable enough movie, I just wish that Bruce Lee's last full movie was just a little better.

This is a cult action thriller, the climax sets are still remembered and in fact this is Bruce Lee's most famous film. This is better than apparently all the other films in the action genre of this type, that is action films about martial arts competitions.

This is it, Bruce Lee's best work and materpiece. He went out with a bang, that's for sure.

Lee goes undercover to an island where illegal tournaments are held and seeks to bust the guy in charge. Sound familar? It should, this movie has inspired tons of games and movies after it. Like The Big Boss, Lee does not do too much fighting until the middle but the movie slowly builds up to the point and keeps you waiting. Although there is a fight earlier on where he is out in the courtyard.

Not to mention, John Saxon and the always awesome Jim Kelley are the co-stars and they are great.

Of course, like every Bruce Lee movie though the best things about this are the fight scenes and Bruce Lee himself. Bruce finally didn't have to use a dub so it's cool to hear his real voice for a change. Great plot, great fights and an awesome cast. Everything came full circle here. This would be Bruce Lee's last movie because I don't count that piece of garbage Game of Death.
Absolutely brilliant, one of my favourite movies ever and bruce lee, awesome :)
It's a shame really, because it's status as a classic movie is not deserved.
The best kung fu film  of all time!!!

Understanding Bruce Lee's role in developing the Martial Arts movie and his skill as a Martial Artist, his movies really weren't very good. Watching a Bruce Lee movie is like watching porn. You fast forward to all the action scenes. The plot is almost non-existent and the dialog is horrible.
This movie has to be one of my favorites.

Pure entertainment, stylish and colorful. Bruce lee is epic but at the end of the day i have to say i find him irritating and obnoxious. Guess thats what makes him bruce lee. Highly unpleasant but bigger than nature. Oh and the music is funky too

The most entertaining and spectaclur kung fu classic film as well as this is my all-the-time favourite Bruce Lee film better than his latest four kung-fu movies. It is a joint American-Chinese production that was intended to be Bruce Lee's introduction to Western audiences, but due to his tragic death just weeks before the film's release.
The plot really resembles a James Bond film in my opinion. Director Robert Clouse does an awesome job with camera work, great shots during the fighting scenes, and keep the film at a very fast pace.
Lee makes an amazing performance as a hero, spiritual and complex character, so is John Saxon who is extremely likable and kicked Bolo Yeung's ass. Kien Shih is fantastic as the main villain, extremely menace and pretty creepy looking.
There are also several cameos made by future Hong Kong martial arts stars that would eventually reach stardom, most notably Jackie Chan (as a henchman during the "Cavern Fight" sequence who has his neck broken by Lee) and Sammo Hung (as Lee's sparring partner in the opening fight sequence).

Highly recommendation!
where has this movie been all my life, Bruce Lee is pure awsome

Almost nothing is better than these insanely great Bruce Lee films. I have viewed my Bruce Lee VSH collection countless amount of times and could watch it hundreds of times again.

Since Bruce Lee pass away, no has been able to replace him. one of the best movie of Bruce Lee!!! EVER!!!

I am a massive fan of Bruce Lee I have all his films and games and Enter The Dragon is his masterpiece. You can tell though that though out the film his loss weight during the film before his death but if you want  to have true Bruce Lee film this is the film.

A martial artist agrees to sp on a reclusive ganglord by accepting his invitation to a martial arts tournament. Enter the Dragon balances well the filmmaking styles of both the countries where the film was produced; the US and Hong Kong. It is also for this reason that perhaps this is one of the most accessible martial arts epics even to this day. But a lot of the credit for this film's reputation goes to Bruce Lee, who hit a high point in his career and worldwide fame with this film, which made his premature death seem more unjust to the eyes of the public that had just discovered his talent and charisma.
love anything with bruce lee
Great action/martial arts film. Good fights, creative sequences, and Bruce Lee.
Nice and enjoyable story but the whole point of this movie is with the stunts, i personally thinks it offers the best stunts within Bruce Lee's anthology
